facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1190 and 1191 of 1969 filed by special leave against judgment dated June 24, 1968 of Orissa High Court in O.J.C. Nos 464 and 463 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1190 and 1191 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 24, 1968 of the Orissa High Court at Cuttack in O.J.C. Nos 464 and 463 of 1967.

facts.text: Respondent in appeal No. 1190 is a dealer registered under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in appeal No. 1190 is a dealer registered under the Act. The matter relates to the assessment for 1963-64.

facts.text: Matter relates to assessment year 1963-64.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to the assessment for 1963-64. The date of the order of assessment is number on file but it is stated that it was made sometime in the later part of 1964.

facts.text: Original assessment order made sometime in later part of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The date of the order of assessment is number on file but it is stated that it was made sometime in the later part of 1964.

facts.text: On March 30, 1967, Sales Tax Officer, Intelligence Wing, Vigilance, Berhampur searched business premises of respondent and seized several account books.

anchor.surface_text: On March 30, 1967 the Sales Tax Officer, Intelligence Wing, Vigilance, Berhampur made a search of the business premises of the respondent and seized several account books.

facts.text: On March 31, 1967, further search made and additional account books taken into possession.

anchor.surface_text: On the following, day further search was made and some additional account books were taken into possession.

facts.text: On March 31, 1967, Sales Tax Officer issued notice under section 12(8) of the Act to M/s Utteswar Rice Mills.

anchor.surface_text: Later on that day, viz, March 31, 1967 the Sales Tax Officer issued the following numberice under section 12 8  of the Act to the respondent Notice to a dealer under section 12 8  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act See rules 22, 23 and 28 2  To M s Utteswar Rice Mills

facts.text: Notice stated belief that turnover for quarter ending 1963-64 escaped assessment or under-assessed.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas I have reason to believe that your turnover for the quarter ending 1963-64 on which Sales Tax was payable under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 has escaped assessment has been under assessed.

facts.text: Notice required return in Form IV within one month, attend on 11-5-67, produce accounts, show cause against penalty.

anchor.surface_text: You are hereby required to submit within one calendar month from the date of receipt of this numberice a return in Form IV  enclosed  showing the particulars of your turnover for the year ending 1963-64. You are also hereby required to attend in person or by agent at my office at Berhampur on 11-5-67 at 1 1 A.M.

facts.text: Notice received by an employee of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice was received by an employee of the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent appeared before Sales Tax Officer and filed copy of old return filed under section 11.

anchor.surface_text: Appearance was thereafter put in on behalf of the respondent before the Sales Tax Officer and a companyy of the old return which had been earlier filed in accordance with section 11 of the Act was again filed before the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: Respondent inquired reasons for notice several times but not informed.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent, appearance was put in on its behalf on several occasions with a view to know the reason for the issue of the above numberice, but the respondent was number informed of that reason.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer recorded statements of witnesses behind respondent's back.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that the Sales Tax Officer recorded the statements of a number of witnesses behind the back of the respondent with the intention of making reassessment under section 12 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent requested copies of witness statements, application rejected by STO.

anchor.surface_text: Request was made on behalf of the respondent to the Sales Tax Officer for being furnished with companypies of those statements so that the respondent might be in a position to know the reason for the issue of the numberice. Copies of those statements were, however, number supplied and the appli- cation filed by the respondent for obtaining companyies of the statements was rejected by the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: Revision petition against rejection of application for copies dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a revision petition against the order rejecting that application, but the revision petition too was dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under articles 226 and 227 on December 26, 1967 in Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter filed petition under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court on December 26, 1967.

facts.text: Orissa High Court quashed notice on ground no reasons indicated, dated June 24, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the writ petition on the ground that the Sales Tax Officer had number indicated any reason for issuing numberice under section 12 8  of the Act. This fact,, in the opinion of the High Court, was sufficient to warrant quashing of the numberice.

facts.text: High Court relied on earlier decision B. Patnaik Mines P Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in this companytext relied upon its earlier decision in the case of B. Patnaik Mines  P  Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty Sales Tax Officer 1 .

facts.text: Affidavit of Shri Prakash Chandra Mohanty states STO issued notice after info on clandestine dealings of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Affidavit of Shri Prakash Chandra Mohanty, Sales Tax Officer, Intelligence Circle was filed in opposition to the petition, Shri Mohanty is the successor of Shri Patnaik who had issued the numberice under section 12 8  of the Act to the respondent.

facts.text: Seized documents disclosed prima facie material that respondent failed to disclose entire turnover.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit of Shri Mohanty, the material on record indicates that Shri Patnaik issued the impugned numberice after he had obtained information about certain clandestine dealings of the respondent. It was further stated that the seized documents disclosed prima facie material to hold that the respondent had failed to disclosehis entire turnover.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court judgment and dismissed writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the view taken by the High Court in the judgment under appeal as well as in the earlier case of B. Patnaik Mines  P  Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty Sales Tax Officer  supra  was number companyrect. We accordingly accept the two appeals, set aside the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the writ petitions.
articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court on December 26, 1967.
articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court on December 26, 1967.

issues.text: Whether notice issued under section 12(8) of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 should be quashed on the ground that it does not mention the reasons for the issue of the notice

anchor.surface_text: Whether numberice issued under section 12 8  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act 14 of 1947   hereinafter referred to as the Act  should be quashed on the ground that it does number mention the reasons for the issue of the numberice is the main question

issues.text: Whether the existence of a reason that the turnover has escaped assessment or has been under-assessed is a condition precedent to the issue of notice under section 12(8) of the Act, and whether such reason existed in the present case

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gobind Das has also argued that the existence of a reason that the turnover of a dealer has escaped assessment or has been under-assessed in cases, number dealing with companyposition is a companydition precedent to the issue of a numberice under section 12 8  of the Act.

issues.text: Whether calling upon the assessee to show cause against penalty in the notice under section 12(8) is premature

anchor.surface_text: Calling upon the respondent to show cause why penalty should number be imposed upon him, according to the learned companynsel, is premature at this stage.

The impugned numberice, according to the learned companynsel, cannot be quashed for number-mention of the reasons.

The earlier stage of the proceedings for recording the reasons of the Income-tax Officer and for obtaining the sanction of the Commissioner are administration in character and are number quasi- judicial.

arguments.claim: Sales Tax Officer must disclose material proposed to be used against dealer before using it in reassessment

anchor.surface_text: At the game time, we would liketo make it clear that if the sales tax officer is in possession of material which he proposes to use against the dealer in proceedings for reassessment, the said officer must before using that material bring it to the numberice of the dealer and give him adequate opportunity to explain

holdings.text: There is nothing in the language of section 12(8) of the Act which either expressly or by necessary implication postulates the recording of reasons in the notice which is issued to the dealer under the above provision of law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language lacks express or implied requirement; adding it would read extra words into statute.

holdings.text: To hold that reasons which led to the issue of the said notice should be incorporated in the notice and that failure to do so would invalidate the notice, would be tantamount to reading something in the statute which, in fact, is not there.

anchor.surface_text: To hold that reasons which led to the issue of the said numberice should be incorporated in thenotice and that failure to do so would invalidate the numberice, would be tantamount to reading something in the statute which, in fact, is number there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Imposing requirement would rewrite statute impermissibly.

holdings.text: We are consequently unable to accede to the contention that the notice under the above provision of law should be quashed if the reasons which led to the issue of the notice are not mentioned in the notice.

anchor.surface_text: We are companysequently unable to accede to the companytention that the numberice under the above provision, of law shouldbe quashed if the reasons which led to the issue of the numberice are number mentioned in the numberice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory basis to quash notice for omitting reasons; supported by IT Act precedents and workable machinery.

holdings.text: if the sales tax officer is in possession of material which he proposes to use against the dealer in proceedings for reassessment, the said officer must before using that material bring it to the notice of the dealer and give him adequate opportunity to explain and answer the case on the basis of that material.

anchor.surface_text: At the game time, we would liketo make it clear that if the sales tax officer is in possession of material which he proposes to use against the dealer in proceedings for reassessment, the said officer must before using that material bring it to the numberice of the dealer and give him adequate opportunity to explain

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principles of natural justice require disclosure of material and opportunity at reassessment stage, post-notice.

holdings.text: it should be the sales tax authority issuing the notice who should have reason to believe that the turnover of a dealer has escaped assessment or has been under-assessed.

anchor.surface_text: looking to the context in which the words are used, we are of the view that it should be the sales tax authority issuing the notice who should have reason to believe that the turnover of a dealer has escaped assessment or has been under-assessed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'If for any reason' interpreted practically as reason to believe by issuing authority; avoids unworkable construction.

holdings.text: In our opinion the view taken by the High Court in the judgment under appeal as well as in the earlier case of B. Patnaik Mines P Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty Sales Tax Officer supra was not correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the view taken by the High Court in the judgment under appeal as well as in the earlier case of B. Patnaik Mines P Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty Sales Tax Officer supra was number correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's requirement of reasons in notice erroneous per statutory interpretation and precedents.

anchor.surface_text: B. Patnaik Mines P Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty Sales Tax Officer1 . It was held in the earlier case that the Sales Tax Officer had numberjurisdiction under section 12 8  of the Act to issue numberice for making a fishing equiry I.L.R. 1967 Cuttack 446.

precedents.case_name: B. Patnaik Mines P Ltd. v. N. K. Mohanty
precedents.cited_proposition: Sales Tax Officer has no jurisdiction under section 12(8) to issue notice without indicating reason for alleged under-assessment, amounting to fishing enquiry

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. Messrs Mahaltram Ramjidas1 [...] 1940 8 I.T.R. 442

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. Messrs Mahaltram Ramjidas1 the Judicial Committee dealt with the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 as it then existed. The section read as under 34, If for any reason income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax has escaped assessment in any year or has been assessed at too low a rate, the Income-tax Officer may, at any time within one year of the end of that year, serve on the person liable to pay tax on such income, profits, or gains, or in the case of a companypany, on the principal officer thereof, a numberice companytaining all or any of the requirements which may be included in a numberice under sub-section  2  of section 22 and may proceed to assess or reassess such income, profits or gains, and the provisions of this Act shall so far as may be, apply accordingly as if the numberice were a numberice issued under that sub-section  1   1940  8 I.T.R. 442.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. Messrs Mahaltram Ramjidas
precedents.cited_proposition: Under section 34 of Income Tax Act 1922 (similar phrasing 'if for any reason'), Income-tax Officer must form belief that income escaped assessment but need not intimate nature of escapement or give opportunity before issuing notice; notice valid without particulars
precedents.cited_holding: the Income-tax Officer is number required by the section to companyvene the assessee,.or to intimate to him the nature of the alleged escapement, or to give him an opportunity of being heard, before he decides to operate the powers companyferred by the section

precedents.cited_proposition: Assessee not entitled to copy of reasons recorded by income tax officer for issuing notice under section 34 of Income Tax Act 1922

Commissioner of Income Tax Bangalore  2   an argument was advanced that the income tax officer should have indicated to the assessee the reasons which  1  1964 52 I.T.R. 355.  2  1967 63 I.T.R. 219 led him to initiate the proceedings under section 34 of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax Officer need not communicate reasons recorded for initiating proceedings under section 34 to the assessee before issuing notice; reasons stage is administrative, not quasi-judicial
